Stuart is at a manager level, while working and performing well in a GM position. He has hence proven to take on these responsibilities and therefore recommend he officially grows to a new JG band which will happen with his transfer to MLIT after the leap.

Stuart joined the leap approx 5 months back and in this very short time frame quickly adapted to the challenge, learned about the projects and the people and was able to put a very strong and motivating team structure in place. Stuart has a very strong people focus and several members in the team have indicated their motivation from being in their role and in the team. He has in a short time made a significant contribution to a number of achievements that both have strong impact to the bottomline (USD 150 mill through reducing operational waste) as well as changed the way we manage our fleet (GPS). The last 2 months have been a bit more difficult with a lot of uncertainty around job potential after the leap and other personal circumstances that have taken some of Stuart's attention away from the job. This has overall resulted in a a very strong 3, rather than a 4 which he would have "earned" if his performance would have stayed at their initial level. All in all, Stuart has performed very well and had a very strong impact on the success of the bunkerleap.
Ideally Stuart will further grow into a leadership role. After the leap he will transfer to MLIT as an individual contributor, but he clearly aspires to take up a leadership role after that.

In my opinion Christian has clear upside managerial and leadership potential and is ready to take the next upwards step in his career.
It is recommended and supported that Christian takes up a role that offers an opportunity to develop and demonstrate commercial business- and people leadership. As Christian has experience from several business units including Maersk Line, Maersk Logistics and Maersk Oil, his next step could either be in a container related - or energy related business unit.

Christian has in his nearly two years working as management PA for me, developed fast and has fully lived up to all expectations and more. He has demonstrated strong analytical skills both financial/economic and in the wider business development and communication aspects. Christian also possesses strong interpersonal skills and is good at 'selling' his points and ensuring buy-in. He has a very strong can do, will do attitude and has delivered to full satisfaction on all tasks given. In addition he possesses an ability to foresee and adapt to a constantly changing environment and thereby exceeding expectations. Christian has clear upside managerial and leadership potential and is ready to take on additional responsibilities including more specific business- and people leadership responsibility at least one organisational level (job grade band) higher than current position.

Christian is interested in developing his business leadership skills and/or strategic analytical skills. Imediate next steps could either be a position within the Strategy & Ecomics team or the New Business team within Maersk Oil. Alternative options could be positions within Maersk Line; Network & Product, the Commercial organisation or a leap role.
Should the opportunity arise, Christian is also very interested in taking up a position as country/cluster manager or sales manager outside DK.

During 2Q09 Maria focused her efforts in CENMKT on the Global Campaign Program identifying new markets, where she successfully assured release of the Iraq campaign on time. On the Iraq campaign Maria had a very collaborative working style which assured that key stakeholders had bought into the project at an early stage plus also actively contributing to the successful development of the campaign.
Marias work with the Iraq campaign has been very elaborate and she has demonstrated hard work, system knowledge and use of network within the APMM organisation (NNP and Clusters).
Feedback on the Iraq campaign from the Clusters and CENMKT have been: Great stakeholder management, Buy in from NNP was very important, Maria was very engaged in target setting for the campaign, Strong collaboration, Intelligence could have been presented in a more user friendly format, Maria could have outlined the trends and conclusions of the analysis better to assure that we got all the right angles and Risk assessment of doing business in Iraq could have been more elaborative.
The Iraq campaign has to date (25.08.09) generated $473.145 in OY closed won ($ 108.686 actual loaded) which is quite impressive and can be linked to Marias efforts in assuring thorough research and buy in to the campaign.
During 1H09 Maria also gave support to BPM with score card management where Peter Leschly has given the following comments: Maria has a good drive and demonstrates high enthusiasm, I feel, that I have a high priority with Maria, Maria is pleasant to work with and she has demonstrated patience in her work with especially China, At times Maria can benefit from taking a more holistic view on things instead of sub optimizing, Through Marias commitments, drive and enthusiasm, she sometimes derails from the specific tasks.
Maria has joined the Equipment Optimization LEAP on 10.08.09.

Description: order management, California tax, optimization exercises, budget submission, communication with vessels, operators, TVO and suppliers.
Feedback: Celia quickly became confident with the order management role, thus requiring very little supervision. She soon learned her way around the huge web of contacts required in order for a lube oil supply to run smoothly and her communication with the different stakeholders is good. Celia has shown a special nag for the more challenging vessel types, such as Tankers and supply vessels, where plan B and C often come into play. This indicates a good overview and an appetite for challenges.
It is not in Celias personality to focus on the detail, but she is very good at overcoming this by being consious of it. This is important in relation to optimization exercises and budgets. Also, she has had several cases where her focus on detail has proven its worth.
Personal development; ability to finish assignments etc

Desciption: Previous managers highlights that Celia has difficulties finishing projects etc without being followed up on. We defined this area of personal development as an objective when Celia joined our department as you cannot succeed in a procurement role if you leave ends open.
Feedback: Celia has worked very consiously with the challenge and has improved beyond my expectations.
Celia likes to work on many things at once, and this can cause her to loose focus. However, she has learned to prioritize her tasks herself as she has matured in the procurement role - she has learned the consequences of loose ends - and she is not afraid of asking her peers for priorities. I therefore feel confident giving her important project and I no longer need to follow up on her. It is, however, important that she continue to work consciously with the challenge if she wants to succeed later in life.

Description: coaching of a close collague with the objective of bringing the colleague up to speed with proactive ways of doing the job, management of communication and orders, and prioritization of work tasks.
Feedback: Celia offered to take on the coaching role herself after experiencing some of the issues that arise from poor order management. The coaching is effiecient. It can be perfected, but given that Celia has no theoretical bagage to fall back on I find that she is doing a very good job. The collague has improved and is happy with the daily coaching sessions. The improvement with the colleague has had a very positive effect on the team.

Description: Optimizing our SOP handbook and find a way to make our procedures easier to understand and thus follow for a newcomer to lube oil procurement.
Feedback: Celia has done an excellent job. She is a creative person and has leaned on her experience from PEX in making an interactive tool which is easy to understand and which covers the most frequent issues that many arise when arranging a lube oil supply. The tool is mostly for newcomers. It has eased the pressure on the rest of the team as newcomers are now able to solve many problems themselves by leaning on this tool.

Working Capital and operational Cash Flow

Following initiatives are found necessary:
We need to establish a monthly report that focuses on the YTD working capital balances and operational cash flow reported by all entities, with focus on external balances (assuming that all internal balances are eliminated). //The report needs to include key ratios, to be able to determine if the working capital balances are at an acceptable level and if there is a development we need to question. //With some focus on working capital balances and continuing questioning to the reporting entities we will develop a knowledge database which tells us what our working capital is made up of. This will also allow us to identify areas which we can focus on to improve our operational cash flow. In connection with the FYE reporting we need to do an analysis of the FYE working capital balances. We need to ensure that all reporting entities have actually considered the balances they report in the FYE, so that we can explain the development in our forecasted operational cash flow. //We should furthermore develop a template where we ask the reporting entities to split their ROY cash flow in to months, to be able to do a consolidated report to Group Finance (ref the one I sent to you below) that makes sense.
